channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Russia’s Missile Strikes May Indicate About Its Weapons Stockpile
item.description: Russia’s assault on Ukraine on Monday raised questions about the capacity of Moscow’s forces to carry out President Vladimir V. Putin’s military calculations.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian rocket serves as a reminder of the relentless bombardment of Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Hong Kong Declines to Seize Superyacht Linked to Russian Oligarch
item.description: The yacht, named Nord, is believed to belong to Alexei Mordashov, an ally of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fu
item.media:description: The superyacht Nord is believed to belong to billionaire Alexei Mordashov in the waters off Hong Kong, on Friday.

item.title: Russia’s Revenge
item.description: After weeks of setbacks on the battlefield, Russia struck civilian targets in Ukraine. But Vladimir Putin’s missiles may not accomplish much.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: How Trump Helped Make Busing Migrants a Republican Tactic
item.description: The idea of sending new arrivals to left-leaning areas circulated in conservative circles for years. It gained traction under Donald J. Trump, and now Republican governors have put it into practice.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Michael C. Bender
item.media:description: Migrant families waiting to board a charter bus in McAllen, Tex., in 2021. In recent weeks, three Republican governors have transported migrants to Democratic-leaning areas as a political stunt.

item.title: In Fight for Congress, a Surprising Battleground Emerges: New York
item.description: After a haywire redistricting process, New York has more congressional battlegrounds than nearly any other state. Even the Democratic campaign chairman is locked in a dead heat.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

item.title: As Hospitals Close Children’s Units, Where Does That Leave Lachlan?
item.description: Adult beds are more lucrative than children’s beds. So as institutions look to boost profit margins, pediatrics are often among the first services to be cut.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner
item.media:credit: Melissa Lukenbaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lachlan’s morning routine involves time with the inhaler after breakfast while preparing for school.

item.title: I.M.F. Warns ‘Stormy Waters’ Ahead for World Economy
item.description: The I.M.F. lowered its growth outlook for 2023 and suggested interest rate hikes could spur a harsh global recession.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Attendees gather inside an atrium at the 2022 Annual Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group, on Monday, in Washington.

item.title: Bank of England Expands Market Intervention to Avoid a ‘Fire Sale’
item.description: In the final week of its emergency bond-buying program, the central bank is expanding its efforts to restore bond market function.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bank of England earlier this month.

item.title: One Nation Under Xi: How China’s Leader Is Remaking Its Identity
item.description: The leader’s nationalist effort to meld ethnic groups, an agenda increasingly central to his rule, is seen as a bulwark against internal divisions and threats from the West.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, meeting with members of ethnic groups in 2015.

item.title: British Official Stresses Threat From China Even Amid Russian Aggression
item.description: The head of Britain’s GCHQ spy agency warned that the West should not lose sight of the technological challenge from China as it deals with the immediate problem of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The director of Britain’s cyber and electronic intelligence agency said he was skeptical about how far China would go to support Russia’s aggression.

item.title: Biden Proposal Could Lead to Employee Status for Gig Workers
item.description: A proposed rule, long awaited by labor activists, would make it harder for companies to classify workers as independent contractors.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gig companies such as Lyft have long fought efforts to classify their drivers as employees.

item.title: New NYC Congestion Pricing Tolls May Lower Demand For Yellow Cabs
item.description: The tolling program could push up fares and shrink taxi demand, the M.T.A. says. Cabdrivers are also seeking their own fare hike of up to 23 percent.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley
item.media:credit: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: The congestion pricing plan could reduce the number of yellow taxis in Manhattan.

item.title: Forget Madden. The Hottest Game in the N.F.L. Is Chess.
item.description: Athletes, known for being gamers, often find ways to compete during their downtime. Football players who tackle chess are drawn to the mental challenge that runs against stereotypes in their sport.
item.dc:creator: Robert O’Connell
item.media:credit: Maddie Malhotra for The New York Times

item.title: Israel and Lebanon Reach Landmark Maritime Agreement
item.description: If ratified by both governments, the deal is expected to avert the immediate threat of conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, and could eventually help salve energy shortages.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: An Israeli navy vessel patrolled the Mediterranean waters off Rosh Hanikra on the border between Israel and Lebanon on Friday.

item.title: Los Angeles Labor Federation Chief Resigns in Furor Over Leaked Conversation
item.description: Ron Herrera was part of a secretly recorded conversation in which the Los Angeles City Council president, Nury Martinez, mocked Indigenous immigrants and the Black child of a fellow council member.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ron Herrera, president of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor, resigned on Monday night.

item.title: Cate Blanchett Doesn’t Want to Be Understood
item.description: The actress has stayed one step ahead of audiences by constantly being in motion. In her new movie “Tár,” she’s as inscrutable as ever.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Kisner and Jack Davison
item.media:description: “You have to allow yourself to be seen, and some people have the gift of being comfortable with that really early on. I was not,” says Blanchett. “I still struggle with it.”

item.title: What Teenagers’ Mental Health Can Tell Us About America
item.description: Adolescents live at the fault lines of a culture, exposing our weak spots.
item.dc:creator: Jamieson Webster
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chantal Jahchan. Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Why Do People Think Going to Therapy Makes You a Good Person?
item.description: The recent focus on therapy as a cure-all overlooks that there are other ways to heal.
item.dc:creator: Mychal Denzel Smith
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; photograph by Getty Images/iStockphoto

item.title: How Facebook Triggers My Bipolar Disorder
item.description: Social media didn’t cause my mental illness, but it exacerbated it. Now I have found a way to quiet the noise.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Eisler Vance
item.media:credit: Tommy Kha for The New York Times

item.title: This Is What Happens When Election Deniers Let Their Freak Flag Fly
item.description: The 2020-was-rigged crowd has ambitious plans.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times

item.title: The Midterms Aren’t the Only Things That Are Looming
item.description: Borders all over the world are in dispute, and they are not all geographical.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:description: An unfinished section of the border wall near Roma, Texas.

item.title: Russia’s New Onslaught Against Ukraine
item.description: Readers respond to the latest Russian attacks in Ukraine. Also: The wonders of math; pandemic spending; Republicans and crime.
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: How I Fell In Love With Loretta Lynn
item.description: Loretta Lynn was complicated. Love is, too.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: The Exploitative Anti-Blackness of Kanye West
item.description: By wearing a “White Lives Matter” shirt, Kanye West gave white supremacists a boost.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: The Rise of the Single-Family Home
item.description: They may have become a cherished feature of American life, but in California, such dwellings are a driver of soaring house prices.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Luke Vander Ploeg, Kaitlin Roberts, Will Reid, Anita Badejo, Rowan Niemisto, Chelsea Daniel and Marion Lozano
item.media:credit: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Baxter Street in San Diego. In the 1950s, the area was marketed as a quiet suburb of single-family homes just a few minutes’ drive from schools and a shopping center, along with downtown and the beach.

item.title: How to Learn My Love Language
item.description: A Deaf man has been let down by every lover he’s ever had. This time might be different.

item.title: Tell Us: What Questions About Climate Change Can We Answer?
item.description: There is no question too basic, or too big. Your suggestions will be used to help guide the Times’s climate coverage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Can This Man Solve Europe’s Energy Conundrum?
item.description: Marco Alverà has big plans to produce a “green gas” from hydrogen that uses existing infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marco Alverà’s synthetic substitute for fossil fuels “can go in the same ships, the same pipes, the same factories,” he said.

item.title: Jennifer Siebel Newsom, Wife of Gov. Gavin Newsom, To Testify in Harvey Weinstein’s L.A. Trial
item.description: Jennifer Siebel Newsom, a documentary filmmaker and former actor, has accused the once-powerful film mogul, Harvey Weinstein, of sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein during a court appearance in Los Angeles last week.

item.title: Why Isn’t Aaron Judge Intentionally Walked More?
item.description: Intentional walks have fallen out of favor, but with every run in the postseason being precious, teams may be tempted to force a different Yankees batter to beat them.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Judge was walked 111 times this season. His 19 intentional walks were the second most in the majors.

item.title: Stewart Rhodes is Not the Only Oath Keeper on Trial
item.description: The stories of the four other members of the far-right militia also facing charges of seditious conspiracy help flesh out the group’s role around the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jared Ramsdell/Journal Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Justice Department set out its case against Stewart Rhodes, above, and four other members of the far-right Oath Keepers militia.

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: Fall Allergies: What to Know About Causes, Symptoms and Care
item.description: Climate change is making this allergy season longer and more intense. Here’s how to cope.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Hangover Anxiety: How a Night of Drinking Can Tank Your Mood
item.description: Consuming alcohol can mess with your emotions the next day by causing stress hormones to spike and sleep to be disrupted overnight.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: What is Microdosing, and Does it Work?
item.description: Scientists are split over whether the benefits some microdosers experience are a placebo effect or something more.
item.dc:creator: Dana G Smith

item.title: How to Spot ‘Medical Gaslighting’ and What to Do About It.
item.description: Experts share tips on advocating for yourself in a health care setting.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Review: Berlin Takes Wagner’s Approach to Staging the ‘Ring’
item.description: All four parts of Wagner’s epic were presented within a week, in a new production by Dmitri Tcherniakov inspired by the work’s experimental roots.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
